"Yes," Elara breathed, the single word a profound and weary admission. "It's a humming in your bones. You can't ever turn it off. Even when you're exhausted, even when you just want to read a book and pretend a neighbour's fence isn't slowly rotting from the inside out… you can still feel it. The splinter, the snag, the sadness in the walls." She looked at Morda, whose eyes were filled with a deep, sorrowful recognition. The gulf between their two worlds, which had once felt so vast, had shrunk to the space of a single, shared, terrible truth. They were two sides of the same cursed coin, one driven to fill the void, the other to patch it. Both of them were denied the simple, un-magical grace of just letting things be. The silence that settled after her admission was not empty. It was a space of deep and solemn communion, a quiet acknowledgment of their shared, strange, and burdensome humanity.

The days that followed were built around this new understanding. Their quiet companionship was no longer just the product of Morda’s fragility; it was a mutual choice, a shared convalescence. They were two veterans of a silent war, learning to live in the quiet landscape of peacetime. Their mornings were spent in the garden, a space that was becoming more Morda’s than Elara’s. Morda, who had once been terrified of the overwhelming vitality of the living world, now moved through it with a quiet, focused purpose. She learned the names of the plants from the worn gardening books Elara left on the kitchen table. She learned to distinguish the aggressive spread of mint from the delicate wandering of creeping thyme. Her hands, which had once dealt only in absence, became instruments of cultivation. She would spend hours carefully loosening the soil around the base of the struggling roses, her touch now gentle, investigative, a coaxing rather than a taking.

And every day, without fail, the first and last ritual was the pot. She would examine the surface of the soil with a forensic intensity, her face inches from the terracotta rim, searching for any sign of change. It was an exercise in pure faith, and with each passing day that the earth remained stubbornly, impassively brown, Elara could feel a faint tension build in her friend. The hope they had so carefully planted was taking its time, and patience was a virtue Morda was only just beginning to learn. The pinwheel stood as a lonely, cheerful sentinel, spinning in the breeze, a colourful distraction from the static, silent earth beneath it.

Then, on the ninth morning, a day of pale, watery sunlight, it happened. Elara was at the kitchen sink, washing the breakfast dishes, when she heard a sharp, indrawn breath from the patio. She turned, her heart lurching, expecting some new crisis. But Morda was not in distress. She was on her knees before the calendula pot, her body rigid, her hands pressed to her mouth. She was staring at the soil with an expression of such fierce, unadulterated awe that Elara felt she was intruding on a sacred moment. Elara dried her hands and stepped outside, her own footsteps silent on the concrete. She knelt beside Morda, following her gaze. And there it was. Pushing through the dark soil was a tiny, perfect arch of pale green. It was not a grand thing. It was barely a thing at all. It was a speck of life so new and so fragile it seemed impossible it could have shouldered its way through the heavy earth. It was a question mark, formed of a stem, not yet ready to unfurl its leaves and face the sun.

"It's here," Morda whispered, her voice choked with a reverence that bordered on fear. She reached out a trembling finger, stopping a millimetre from the tiny sprout, as if her touch might shatter it. "It heard me." Elara knew she didn't mean it in a literal sense. She meant that the world had answered. She meant that her act of faith, of planting a seed in the darkness, had been acknowledged. The life that she had once instinctively sought to extinguish had chosen, in its own time, to meet her halfway. She stayed there, kneeling on the hard concrete for a long time, simply watching the sprout, as if guarding it, her face a study in wonder and a deep, soul-shaking relief. The pinwheel above spun and whirred, a silent, joyful applause for the smallest, most significant victory in the history of the world.

The appearance of the sprout changed everything. It was proof of concept. It was a miracle Morda had co-authored. A new energy began to hum in her, a quiet but persistent thrum of purpose. The next day, there were three more sprouts. The day after that, the first two had unfurled their cotyledons, their first two fat, simple seed-leaves, like a pair of open arms embracing the sun. Morda began to spend more time with the gardening books than she did staring into space. She started a list, written in a shaky but determined hand on a piece of scrap paper. 'Basil. Chives. Something for the bees.' Her world was expanding from the single pot to the potential of the whole garden. The devourer, who had sought to make the world smaller, was now actively looking for ways to fill its empty spaces with life.

One afternoon, as they sat on the patio, watching a fat bumblebee investigate the lamb’s ear, Morda turned to Elara, her expression serious. "Do you still feel it?" she asked. Elara knew instantly what she meant. The hum. The static. The call of things that needed mending. "It's quieter," Elara admitted. "Since you… came back. It's like my attention is all used up here. There's not enough left over to hear the little things. The sad walls and the rusty hinges." Morda nodded, her gaze turning inward. "I don't feel the hunger," she said, the words a quiet confession. "But I feel… an echo. An emptiness where it used to be. It’s cold." She looked down at her hands, then back at Elara. "When I was weeding, and I touched that worm… I felt it. The life. It didn't hurt. It just felt… loud. And when I look at the sprouts, I can feel them. Not like before. Not a thing to be consumed. It’s like I can feel them *trying*. It's so small, but it's… fierce." Her eyes were wide with a kind of fearful wonder. "My magic… it’s not gone. It’s just… quiet. And it doesn’t know what it’s for anymore."Morda’s quiet confession, the acknowledgment of a magic that was no longer a weapon but a strange, vestigial limb, changed the atmosphere of the house more than any physical event had. It was a secret laid bare, a vulnerability so profound it demanded a new kind of intimacy. The cold emptiness she described, the hollow space where the all-consuming hunger had once been, was a landscape Elara could not imagine, yet the feeling of being saddled with a power that offered no rest was a language she understood perfectly. They were two anomalies, sitting in the soft light of a Langley evening, finally able to see the strange and burdensome shape of each other’s souls. The quiet work of the garden and the workshop had been about healing the past; this conversation was the first, tentative step into defining a future.

The next morning, the air was charged with the memory of that shared vulnerability. After their silent breakfast, Morda was drawn, as always, to the patio. The calendula sprouts, now a small crowd of determined green hooks and tiny, unfurled leaves, seemed to have grown visibly overnight. Morda knelt before the pot, her usual morning ritual, but this time it was different. There was a new intensity to her gaze, a focused, searching quality. Elara watched from the kitchen doorway as Morda slowly, hesitantly, raised a hand and held it hovering a few inches above the surface of the soil. Her eyes were closed, her face a mask of concentration, and Elara could feel the shift in the air, the faint, familiar disturbance of magic being gathered. It was not the vast, sucking void of the Devourer, but a small, focused point of cold, directionless energy. Morda was reaching out with her quieted magic, but the force was inert, a tool with no function, and Elara could feel the rising tide of frustration and fear in her.

She was afraid of what her touch might still do. The muscle memory of her power was one of destruction, of taking, of leaving things withered and less than they had been. Elara saw the tremor in her hovering hand, the slight furrowing of her brow as she fought against the ingrained fear that her very nature was still toxic. Quietly, Elara stepped out onto the patio, her bare feet cool on the concrete. Morda’s eyes flew open, startled, and her hand dropped as if she’d been caught doing something forbidden. A flush of shame coloured her pale cheeks. "I didn't…" she began, her voice trailing off, unable to explain what she hadn’t done. Elara knelt beside her, bringing herself to the same level, her gaze soft and understanding. "I know," she said quietly. "You weren't taking. But you don't know how to give."

Elara gestured to the pot, to the tiny, fierce green lives pushing their way into the world. "You said you can feel them trying," she said. "That’s the key. Your magic used to be a demand. A shout into the world to give you what you needed. It was all about you. This," she pointed a finger at a particularly sturdy sprout, "is not about you. Don't try to push anything into it. Don't try to give it warmth or strength or anything you feel you don't have. That’s not how it works." She paused, gathering her thoughts, trying to translate the ingrained, intuitive nature of her own craft into words. "Just listen to it. Feel that 'trying' you talked about. And… agree with it. Your magic is a focusing of will. So focus. Agree with its will to live. Be a whisper in the background, not a voice in the foreground. Tell it, 'Yes. Grow.'"

Morda stared at her, her dark eyes wide with a mixture of hope and terror. A whisper. Agree with it. It was a completely alien concept. Her power had only ever known how to disagree with life, how to say ‘No. Be less. Be nothing.’ She looked from Elara’s calm, patient face back to the pot of determined sprouts. Taking a deep, ragged breath that was half-sob, she raised her hand again. This time, Elara placed her own hand lightly on Morda’s shoulder, a grounding point of contact, a silent offering of support. Morda closed her eyes, and Elara could feel the struggle as she wrestled with her own instincts. She felt the gathering of that cold, purposeless energy, but then, following Elara’s instruction, Morda did not try to shape it or push it. Instead, she simply let it be, and directed her entire consciousness, her entire intention, into a single, silent, focused thought aimed at the small green lives in the pot. *Yes. Grow.*

For a long moment, nothing happened. The world was still. The sun was warm. The pinwheel was motionless in the still air. Elara could feel the faint, cold hum of Morda’s magic, no longer a void but a focused, attentive presence, a quiet and intense form of listening. And then, it happened. It was not a flash of light or a sudden, dramatic growth. It was far more subtle, and far more profound. One of the smallest sprouts, a tiny arch that had been struggling to break free of its own seed casing, gave a faint, almost imperceptible tremor. The seed casing, which had been stubbornly clinging to its unfurled leaves, fell away, landing softly on the dark soil. The two tiny leaves, freed from their final constraint, opened to the sun. It was a microscopic drama, a tiny, silent victory, but its impact was seismic.

Tears began to stream from under Morda’s closed eyelids, silent, hot tears that dripped from her chin onto her clasped hands in her lap. She did not make a sound, but her shoulders shook with the force of a sob that was too deep for noise. She had touched the world with her magic, the same magic that had blighted farms and killed birds and drained the life from a botanical garden, and it had not resulted in death. It had resulted in release. In a tiny, but undeniable, flourishing of life. Elara kept her hand on Morda’s shoulder, a silent witness to the shattering and rebuilding of a universe. The Devourer was truly dead. In her place, kneeling in the dirt on a sunny Langley patio, was a gardener.The smile was a sunrise after a biblical flood, a slow dawning that promised a new and fundamentally altered world. It was a smile born not of happiness, but of a profound and soul-deep relief, the relief of a lifetime exile finally being given a map home, even if the journey was still impossibly long. “A clearer of the path.” The words settled in the quiet morning air, and in their resonance, both women felt the solidifying of a new reality. Morda was no longer defined by the monstrous thing she had been, nor by the hollow ghost she had become. She was now a collection of possibilities, a practitioner of a craft that was only just beginning to be named. The weight of that potential, of a purpose that was not destructive, was a burden of a different kind, but it was a burden Morda seemed, for the first time, willing to carry.

The days that followed took on a new texture, a rhythm of quiet, shared scholarship. The house, which had been a sickroom and then a silent monastery, became a laboratory. Morda, armed with her nascent identity, began to explore the nature of her strange, cold magic with a cautious, scientific curiosity. The garden was her primary field of study. She would spend hours kneeling in the dirt, not just weeding, but observing, sensing. She would hold her hand over a rose bush, not trying to change it, but simply feeling it, discerning the difference between the vibrant energy of a living cane and the faint, fading signature of a dead one. "This one," she would murmur, pointing to a woody, leafless stalk. "Its story is over." And Elara, following her, would prune the deadwood away, the snip of her shears a neat, affirmative punctuation to Morda’s quiet diagnosis. They became a strange, symbiotic team: Morda the diagnostician of endings, Elara the facilitator of the subsequent new beginning.

Their conversations, once nonexistent, became a central part of their evenings. They would sit at the small kitchen table, surrounded by Elara’s worn gardening books and Morda’s growing collection of seed packets, and they would talk. Morda, with a hesitant, halting voice, would try to describe the internal landscape of her power. She described it as a lens that could bring the concept of ‘finished’ into sharp focus. A bruised apple, an autumn leaf, a frayed thread—to her re-attuned senses, they didn’t just look old or damaged; they possessed a distinct energetic signature, a quality of having completed their purpose. The hunger, she explained, had been a corruption of this sense, a frantic, indiscriminate application of ‘finished’ to everything she encountered, driven by the broken belief that everything was ultimately worthless and better off over. Now, she was learning discernment, learning to read the subtle grammar of conclusion, to see an ending not as a failure, but as a natural and necessary state.

Elara, in turn, found herself articulating the nature of her own magic in a way she never had before. She explained the hum, the constant, low-level call of things that were out of alignment, the pull of a mismatched sock, the sorrow of a neglected house, the jangled nerves of a lost pet. "It's a call for re-integration," she explained, a concept solidifying in her own mind even as she spoke it. "It's about reminding things of their place in the whole, of their connection to everything else. Mending a tear in a shirt isn’t just about the thread; it’s about restoring the shirt to its purpose as a garment, a thing of use and comfort." Morda listened with a rapt, focused attention, recognizing the echoes of her own experience. "So you feel the disconnection," she murmured, "and I feel the completion." Elara nodded, a sense of awe dawning on her. "We're readers," she said, the realization striking her with the force of a revelation. "We're just reading different parts of the same book."

One afternoon, Morda stood in the doorway of Elara’s workshop, no longer a hesitant observer but a collaborator with a problem. In her hand, she held a single, perfect maple leaf, turned a brilliant, fiery red. She had found it in the garden, a lone scout of the coming autumn. "Feel this," she said, holding it out to Elara. Elara took the leaf, its surface smooth and dry. To her senses, it was beautiful, a perfect specimen of autumnal change, but it was just a leaf. "It's lovely," she said. Morda shook her head, a familiar frustration in her eyes. "No, feel it with your magic." Elara closed her eyes and reached out with her other senses, the part of her attuned to the flow. She felt the fading memory of chlorophyll, the ghost of its connection to the tree, the slow, graceful process of its life cycle drawing to a close. It was a quiet, peaceful signature. "It's letting go," Elara said. "It's finished its work."

"Exactly," Morda said, her voice tight with excitement. "Now, watch." She took the leaf back from Elara and placed it on the workbench. Closing her eyes, she held her hand over it, and Elara felt the familiar, focused gathering of that quiet, cold energy. Morda was not pushing, not demanding, but simply agreeing with the leaf’s own state of being. *Yes*, the magic seemed to whisper. *You are finished.* The leaf did not wither or turn to dust. Instead, the brilliant red deepened, became more vibrant, more intensely itself, as if all its remaining life force was being focused into a final, perfect expression of its colour. Then, with a sigh so soft it was barely audible, the leaf’s stem crisped and curled, and the entire leaf collapsed into a pile of fine, ruby-coloured dust, as beautiful and richly hued as any pigment. There was no sense of violence, no feeling of destruction. It was a clean, quiet, and breathtakingly elegant conclusion. Both women stared at the small pile of red dust, a testament to a power that had found its true and proper purpose. Morda had not destroyed the leaf; she had helped it achieve its most perfect and complete ending.The small pile of ruby dust on the workbench became a new kind of altar. It was a testament not to a god or a spirit, but to a possibility, a single, elegant data point in a brand new field of study. In the days that followed, the quiet bungalow, once a hermitage and then a hospital, transformed again, this time into a research facility of the most unusual kind. Its subject was the nature of endings, and its two researchers were uniquely, if tragically, qualified for the work. Their laboratory was the house and garden, and their experiments were conducted on the forgotten, the broken, and the things that had gracefully reached the end of their stories.

It began in the kitchen, with a bowl of fruit Elara had forgotten on the counter. A single pear had gone soft, its skin bruised and wrinkled, a sweet, fermented scent beginning to rise from it. To Elara’s senses, it was a discordant note, a life process tipping over into the messy chaos of decay. To Morda, who paused beside the counter, it was something else. "This one," she murmured, her voice now possessing a quiet, diagnostic authority. "It's ready." Elara watched as Morda held her hand over the fruit. There was no struggle now, no fear. There was only a calm, focused application of her will, a quiet agreement with the pear’s inevitable fate. The fruit did not rot or liquefy. Instead, it sighed, collapsing in on itself, its form dissolving into a small mound of fine, cinnamon-coloured powder that smelled sweetly of honey and cider. Morda looked at the neat, dry pile, then at Elara, a look of quiet wonder on her face. "It doesn’t have to be ugly," she whispered.

Each successful ‘completion’ was a quiet act of self-reclamation. It was a painstaking process of writing over the horrific muscle memory of her former power. The Devourer had been a blunt instrument, a cudgel that battered life into nothingness. This new application was a scalpel, precise and clean, used not to wound but to perform a final, respectful severance. The cold echo inside her, the space where the hunger had lived, was still there. It was a permanent feature of her internal landscape, a hollow canyon carved by years of grief and self-annihilation. But she was learning that it was not just a void. It was also a lens. It was the source of her unique and terrible perception, the apparatus that allowed her to see the intricate, delicate beauty of a thing’s final, coherent moments before it dissolved into the universe’s background noise. It was no longer a source of shame, but the very tool of her newfound craft.

Elara’s role, in turn, evolved from that of a caregiver to a vital collaborator. Her own magic, the gentle, persistent call to mend and reintegrate, found a new and profound application. She became Morda’s spotter, her guide through the world of things. She would walk through the house, letting her senses drift, not looking for things to fix, but for their opposite. She would find a book whose spine was so thoroughly broken that its pages were ready to scatter, a wool sock that had been darned so many times it was more thread than wool, a teacup with a web of hairline cracks that made it unfit to hold liquid. These were objects beyond the purview of her mending, things whose purpose had been honorably served. She would bring them to Morda, a quiet offering for their shared work. In doing so, she found that the constant, nagging hum of the wider world began to fade. Her focus, once spread thin across a township of small sadnesses, was now consumed by the deep, complex, and singular act of restoration happening within her own walls. Her world had become smaller, but its meaning had become infinitely more dense.

The workshop became their formal laboratory. They moved beyond the transient lives of fruits and leaves to the more stubborn histories of inanimate objects. One day, Elara brought Morda an old leather gardening glove she had found in the back of a shed. It was stiff with age, the fingers cracked and curled into a permanent, arthritic claw, the stitching long since rotted away. It was an object saturated with the memory of past work, but its own working days were unequivocally over. Morda held it in her hands, her eyes closed, feeling its story. She felt the ghost of the hand that had worn it, the memory of soil and thorns, the seasons of planting and pruning. Then she placed it on the workbench and held her hand over it, her focus absolute. The leather did not burn, but fumed, dissolving into a fibrous, umber-coloured dust that smelled richly of tanned hide and dry earth and faint, phantom sweat. The ending was always true to the essence of the thing itself. An ending was not a singular event, but a unique and final expression of a life’s story.

Elara, the quiet keeper of glittering secrets, became a curator of endings. She found a set of small, glass apothecary jars in a dusty antique store and brought them home. With a steady hand, she began to catalogue their work. One jar was filled with the ruby dust of the first maple leaf. Another held the cinnamon powder of the pear. A third was filled with the umber dust of the gardener's glove. Each was labelled in Elara’s neat, careful script: *Acer circinatum, Autumn. Pyrus communis, Overripe. Glove, Worn.* The collection grew on a shelf in the workshop, a strange and beautiful library of conclusions. Morda would sometimes stand before it, her fingers tracing the glass, her gaze moving over the spectrum of quiet, colourful dusts. She was looking at a tangible record of her own power, not as a force of negation, but as one of transformation. The jars were a profound counter-narrative to her father’s despairing cry that everything was worthless. Here was the proof that even in their final, finished state, things retained their colour, their scent, their essential character. Here was proof that even an ending could have substance.

One evening, they stood together before the growing collection. The setting sun slanted through the workshop window, illuminating the small jars, making them glow like captured sunsets. Morda reached out and touched the jar containing the glove’s dust, a thoughtful, distant look on her face. “It’s funny,” she said, her voice soft and even. “For all those years, all I wanted was to make everything quiet. To turn down the volume of the whole world until it was as silent as I was. But this…” She gestured to the jars, to the pot of thriving calendula visible through the window, to the quiet, ordered peace of the room. “This quiet is different. It isn’t empty. It’s… full.” She turned to Elara, and her eyes, once voids of hunger, were now clear and deep, reflecting the warm, fading light. “Thank you,” she said, the two words holding the weight of a salvaged universe. “You didn’t just mend me. You gave my magic a new story to tell.”

The rain didn't so much fall as it seeped from a sky the colour of a tired bruise. It was a typical Langley Tuesday, the air thick with the scent of damp cedar and exhaust fumes from the traffic crawling along Fraser Highway. From her window, Elara watched a raven shake its water-slicked feathers on a hydro wire, its obsidian eye seeming to fix on her small bungalow. She felt a kinship with the bird—a watcher, a keeper of small, glittering secrets. Her own secret was a craft woven from intention and the subtle energies that coiled, unseen, around the manicured lawns and vinyl-sided houses of the Township.

Her particular set of skills, as she privately and ironically called them, were not the stuff of fireballs and grand incantations. Elara was a finder, a mender, a whisperer to the forgotten things. She could coax a lost earring from a vacuum bag with a thought, soothe the jangled nerves of a panicked cat from across the street, and read the history of a place from the residue of emotions left clinging to its walls. Her magic was quiet, practical, and above all, discreet. It was the magic of a woman who wanted to be left alone, who found solace in the quiet hum of a world set right.

Today, however, the hum was off-key. It had been for a week. A faint, discordant note had crept into the background music of her life, a persistent, low-grade static that prickled the hairs on her arms. It was a feeling of *less*. As if a colour had been leached from the world, so subtly that no one else would ever notice. But Elara noticed. It was her job to notice.

She closed her eyes, letting the familiar drone of the refrigerator fade away. She cast her senses outward, not with her eyes or ears, but with the part of her that was attuned to the flow. She let her awareness drift past the gossiping thoughts of her neighbour, Brenda, past the anxious buzz of a teenager late for his shift at the Tim Hortons, past the sleepy contentment of the old dog down the block. She was looking for the void, the place where the energy wasn't flowing correctly. It was a technique akin to running a hand over a smooth sheet of silk, searching for the snag.

And there it was. A gaping, silent tear in the fabric. It wasn't a violent rip, but a slow, steady unraveling. The source was south, towards the Nicomekl River, in the manicured heart of Sendall Botanical Gardens. A knot of cold dread tightened in her stomach. That was a place of cultivated life, of vibrant, focused energy. For it to feel so… empty… was deeply wrong.

Elara pulled on her worn Blundstones and a waterproof jacket that had seen better decades. She didn't bother with an umbrella; the rain was a part of the world she worked with, not an inconvenience to be avoided. The short drive was a study in contrasts. The world outside her windshield looked normal. Rain-slicked roads, green signs pointing the way to wineries and historical sites, people huddled in the doorways of coffee shops. Yet, to her senses, it was like driving through a landscape where the volume was slowly being turned down. The vibrant life-force of the blooming rhododendrons seemed muted, the sturdy stoicism of the Douglas firs felt brittle.

She parked in the nearly empty lot at Sendall Gardens. Usually, even in the rain, there would be a few hardy souls, dog-walkers and garden enthusiasts. Today, there was only one other car, a mud-splattered Subaru. The silence that greeted her as she stepped out of her car was profound. It wasn't the peaceful quiet of a rainy garden. It was a dead quiet. The cheerful chirping of the sparrows that usually populated the hedges was gone. The susurrus of the wind through the canopy was flat, lifeless.

Walking under the grand wooden archway, she felt the wrongness press in. The air was thin, carrying a faint, cloying sweetness, like rotting fruit and burnt sugar. The famous dahlia beds, which should have been a riot of crimsons, yellows, and purples, looked like a faded photograph of their former selves. The colours were there, technically, but the vibrancy was gone. They were just shapes, husks of what they should have been.

Elara ran her fingers over a drooping peony blossom. It felt dry and papery, despite the rain clinging to its petals. The life within it, the tiny spark of botanical will that pushed it towards the sun, was gone. Not faded. Gone. It had been consumed.

A shiver, cold and sharp, traced its way down her spine. There was only one kind of magic she knew of that did this. It was a greedy, desperate, and profoundly ugly form of the craft. It didn't borrow or channel energy; it devoured it. Wholly. It was the magic of a bottomless pit, a hunger that could never be sated.

"Gloomy in here today, isn't it?"

Elara startled, her hand dropping from the flower. A woman with a bright pink rain slicker and a frantic-looking terrier on a leash stood a few feet away. It was Brenda from three doors down, her face a mask of cheerful concern.

"Brenda. Hi," Elara managed, forcing a small, tight smile. "Just getting some air."

"You and me both. Though I don't know what for. Place gives me the creeps today," Brenda said, tugging on the leash as the terrier, Pip, whined and tried to retreat towards the parking lot. "Even Pip feels it. Usually he's trying to chase squirrels up every tree. Today he won't even pee. It’s like the whole garden’s holding its breath."

Brenda couldn't see the truth of it, but she could feel the echo. Most people could, on some level. They'd call it an off-day, a weird vibe, bad feng shui. They wouldn't know they were walking through the aftermath of a psychic feeding.

"The rain, I guess," Elara offered, the lie tasting like ash in her mouth. "Makes things feel a bit grim."

"Tell me about it. Well, I'm not sticking around. This is depressing. You take care, Elara. Don't catch a chill." Brenda gave a brisk wave and practically dragged the reluctant Pip back towards the entrance.

Elara watched her go, the gulf between their two worlds feeling wider and deeper than ever. She was alone with the silence again. A predator's silence. She turned from the main path, pushing her way through a hedge of overgrown salal, following the pull of the emptiness. It grew stronger as she moved towards the secluded duck pond at the garden's centre. Here, the effect was devastating. The water, usually a murky green teeming with life, was still and black, reflecting the grey sky with a glassy, dead sheen. The cattails at its edge were brown and brittle, and on the surface, a single, dead mallard floated, its green head a patch of dull colour on the black water.

Her gaze swept the area, looking for the epicentre. And then she saw it. On a stone bench overlooking the dead pond, there was a stain. A dark, greasy patch on the porous stone, shimmering with a faint, sickening iridescence, like oil on a puddle. It was a residue, an effluvium of pure consumption. Kneeling, she held her hand a few inches above it, careful not to touch. The cold was intense, a soul-deep chill that had nothing to do with the temperature. And within that cold, she could feel the psychic signature, the ghost of the presence that had been here.

It was a signature of ravenous, frantic, gluttonous hunger. A need so vast and so deep it sought to fill itself with the very life of the world. A signature she hadn't felt in five years. Not since she'd driven it out of Fort Langley, leaving a trail of blighted farmland and spiritually exhausted livestock in its wake.

Morda.

The name was a sour pit in her stomach. Morda, the Devourer. Morda, whose hunger was her only defining feature. Morda, who had once been a friend, a very long time ago, before the hunger had eaten away everything else.

Elara stood up, her jaw tight. This wasn't a random occurrence. Morda knew she was here. This was a message. A challenge. *I am here. I am hungry. And this little world you've built for yourself looks delicious.* The quiet life she had so carefully constructed, the delicate balance she maintained in her small corner of the world, was over. The static had resolved into a clear and present threat.

She walked back to her car, her movements stiff. The rain was coming down harder now, plastering her hair to her forehead, but she barely noticed. The raven was gone from the hydro wire. The world was no longer just a place of quiet hums and subtle energies. The predator was back in the preserve. And Elara, the quiet keeper of forgotten things, would have to become a hunter again.

The drive back to her bungalow was a blur of green and grey. The world that had seemed merely muted on the way to the gardens now felt fragile, a paper-thin reality stretched over a growing void. Every laughing person she saw, every flash of bright-coloured signage for a local farm market, felt like a personal affront, a reminder of the life Morda would so casually extinguish to feed her gnawing emptiness. Elara gripped the steering wheel, her knuckles white. She was the only one who could see the rot spreading beneath the surface of the everyday, the only one who knew the wolf was not just at the door, but was already inside the fold, tasting the sheep.

Her small house, usually a bastion of comforting energy, now felt like a target. The carefully tended lavender bushes lining the walkway seemed to shiver as she approached, their placid purple essence curdled with a faint note of fear. Inside, the quiet was no longer peaceful. It was the held-breath silence of a place trying to make itself small, to go unnoticed. She locked the deadbolt, a futile gesture against a threat that didn't use doors. The hum of the refrigerator, her familiar baseline, was drowned out by the memory of the dead, glassy pond and the greasy stain on the stone bench. Morda's calling card.

She bypassed the living room and kitchen, heading straight for the small spare bedroom she used as a workshop. The air in here was different, thicker, humming with the residue of her own quiet work. It was a space of order and intention. Jars of sorted sea glass lined one shelf, each piece holding a memory of a storm. On another sat a collection of shed birds' nests, intricate weaves of grass and forgotten string, each a testament to hope and creation. A large, detailed map of the Fraser Valley was pinned to the wall, crisscrossed with faint, shimmering lines only she could see—the ley lines, the energetic currents of the land. This was her sanctuary, and her armoury.

To fight Morda, you couldn't use force. It was like trying to punch a hole in the ocean. The Devourer’s power was absence, a negation, and throwing energy at it was like tossing kindling into a furnace. It would only make her stronger. Elara’s defence, her only real weapon, was the opposite of absence. It was presence. It was the dense, unshakeable reality of things that were deeply and truly *themselves*. She ran her hands along a row of wooden boxes. From one, she pulled a child’s silver locket, tarnished with age but so saturated with a century of a family’s love that it felt warm to the touch. From another, she retrieved a hagstone, a small, flat rock with a natural hole through its centre, found on the shores of a holy island and steeped in the tireless energy of the tides. Lastly, she took a small, leather-bound pouch filled with salt from a dried-up ancient sea, each crystal a memory of life that had been. These were not weapons; they were anchors. They were shields made of stories.

The last time, in the fields outside the old fort, it had nearly broken her. To push Morda back, she had had to pour her own essence into the land, reinforcing its life, its history, its sense of self, until there was nothing left for Morda to consume. It had left Elara a hollowed-out husk for months, the world a grey, tasteless thing until her own energy slowly, painstakingly seeped back in. She had sworn never to engage that way again, choosing instead this quiet life of mending small tears in the fabric, not fighting the one who did the rending. She saw Morda’s face in her mind’s eye, not the gaunt, haunted visage of the Devourer, but the face of the laughing girl who had once taught her how to find four-leaf clovers by feeling for their little spark of luck. The memory was an ache that never truly faded, a reminder that the monster had once been a person, had once been her friend.

That grief was a luxury she couldn't afford now. Resignation settled over her, heavy as a wool blanket soaked in rain. She spread the large map out on her workbench, the locket, stone, and salt pouch laid carefully at its edges like weights. Closing her eyes, she placed her palms flat on the paper. She let go of the frantic energy of her own fear and reached out with her senses, not for the hum of life, but for its opposite. She was no longer running her hand over silk looking for a snag. She was now a cartographer of decay, mapping the blight. She ignored the healthy, vibrant pulse of the towns, the steady thrum of the river, and looked for the spreading stain. It appeared in her mind’s eye as a dark, creeping bruise, centred on the dead heart of Sendall Gardens. From it, a faint, hungry tendril was already snaking west, following the path of the Nicomekl River as it wound towards the sea. Morda wasn't just sending a message. She was on the move.

The tendril was lazy, insidious, hugging the low-lying wetlands that bordered the river. It wasn't a rampaging fire but a creeping mould, patiently finding the path of least resistance. In her mind’s eye, she saw it brush against a small hobby farm known for its organic blueberries. The vibrant, life-affirming energy of the carefully tended bushes flickered, dimming like a faulty bulb. She saw it touch the edge of a protected bird sanctuary, and the frantic, twittering panic of the nesting swallows went quiet, replaced by a confused torpor. Morda wasn't just feeding; she was tasting, sampling the buffet Elara called home, moving with a gourmand's leisure towards the richer energies of the coastline.

The thought of Morda reaching the ocean, a vast, ancient reservoir of primordial life, sent a jolt of pure terror through her. Morda by the sea would be Morda empowered beyond anything Elara could imagine, a black hole anchored to the world’s most powerful battery. This wasn't a challenge anymore. This was a threat of annihilation, quiet and incremental, but total. The time for hiding was over. The time for mending small tears was past. You couldn't patch a sail while a kraken was pulling the whole ship under.

She pushed away from the map, her course of action stark and unavoidable. She couldn’t face Morda at the source; the concentration of nothingness at Sendall was too absolute. She would be consumed before she took two steps. But she could go to the edge of the blight, to the places it was just beginning to touch. She could reinforce them, weave the threads of life and story and history back into a tapestry so dense and strong that Morda’s hunger would find no purchase. It was a strategy of containment, of shoring up the levees before the flood.

From a dusty cabinet beneath her workbench, she pulled a canvas satchel. Into it went the locket, the hagstone, and the pouch of ancient salt. She added a ball of twine spun from the wool of a sheep that had weathered a once-in-a-century storm, and a small, smooth stone she had pulled from the Fraser River years ago, a stone that hummed with the steady, implacable patience of flowing water. They were small things, mundane things. But each was a focal point, an anchor of reality against Morda’s encroaching void. They were prayers made solid.

Stepping back outside was a physical shock. The world hadn't just been muted; it was now faintly out of focus, as if she were looking at it through a cheap, warped piece of glass. The scent of damp cedar was gone, replaced by the smell of wet dust. The rain itself felt different, no longer a cleansing, life-giving force, but a sterile, empty wetness. Her own bungalow, her carefully constructed sanctuary, seemed to shrink behind her, its protective aura pulled in tight like a snail retreating into its shell. She was leaving its fragile safety, stepping into the path of the blight.

Her destination was a small, unnamed parkette that bordered the Nicomekl, a place she knew the tendril was approaching. The drive was shorter this time, but far more unsettling. She passed a soccer field where a youth practice was underway. The shouts of the players were thin, lacking their usual boisterous energy. The thud of the ball against their cleats sounded flat, distant. They were moving, running, but it was a pantomime of sport, their youthful exuberance already being siphoned away, so subtly they would only feel it later as an unusual weariness, a day they just couldn't seem to get going.

She parked on a gravel shoulder beside the parkette. It was a simple place: a few picnic tables, a short loop of trail through the cottonwoods, and a wooden footbridge over a meandering tributary of the river. The wrongness here was a palpable cold that seeped through the soles of her Blundstones. It was the feeling of a room just after someone has left, but this was a presence that had taken the warmth with it. The usual chorus of frogs from the wetlands was absent. The gentle burble of the tributary was a thin, metallic trickle. This was the edge. The place where life was losing its argument with entropy.

Elara walked to the centre of the small footbridge, the weathered wood groaning under her weight. Below, the water was dark and sluggish, its surface reflecting nothing. She could feel the creeping edge of the void, a psychic numbness that sought to leech the intention from her very thoughts. It whispered of pointlessness, of the comfort of giving up, of the sweet relief of simply letting go and becoming nothing. It was Morda’s oldest, most effective weapon: the siren song of despair.

She set her satchel down and took out the river stone. It felt cool in her palm, a familiar, grounding weight. Closing her eyes, she ignored the insidious whispers and focused on the stone itself. She poured her intention into it, not with a burst of power, but with a quiet and stubborn act of memory. She remembered the river’s relentless journey to the sea, the weight of the winter snows it carried from the mountains, the heat of the summer sun on its surface, the feel of salmon fighting their way upstream. She remembered its history, its purpose, its unyielding nature. The stone in her hand grew warmer, a tiny ember of reality glowing against the encroaching cold. With a quiet prayer to the river itself, a plea for it to remember its own strength, she leaned over the railing and dropped the stone into the dark water below. There was no splash, only a soft *plink* as it vanished, but a moment later, a slow, almost imperceptible pulse spread out from where it had landed. A ripple, not on the water, but in the very fabric of the place.

The ripple was not a thing to be seen, but to be felt. It was a slow, deep thrum that resonated up through the wooden piles of the bridge, into the soles of her feet. The suffocating pressure on the air lessened, creating a space to breathe. A single, hesitant frog, hidden in the reeds, let out a tentative croak. The black, lifeless surface of the water below her stirred, a faint current disturbing the dead calm, and for a moment, the grey sky reflected in it looked less like a shroud and more like a simple, overcast day. The whisper of despair in her mind receded, replaced by the steady, patient hum of the river stone, now nested in the muddy creek bed, a tiny beacon of persistence. It was a victory, but it was the victory of a single sandbag against a rising tide.

Elara pulled her senses back, feeling the sting of the cold that clung to the edges of her small sanctuary. In her mind’s eye, the map of the valley reappeared, the dark tendril of Morda’s hunger now curling around the pinprick of light she had just created. It hadn’t been stopped, merely inconvenienced. The void was patient. It would flow around her anchor, seeking easier, softer places to feed. One anchor wasn't a wall; it was a post. To build a fence, she would need more. Many more. A line of them, stretching from the river to the low-slung mountains to the south, a psychic hedge against the Devourer. A wave of profound weariness washed over her. Each anchor would cost her, draining her own reserves to awaken the power in the object, to remind the world of itself. She was attempting to relight a city one candle at a time, while a hurricane raged just offshore.

There was no time for rest. The blight was still moving. She consulted the shimmering ley lines on her mental map, looking for the next nexus point, a place where energy and history converged, a place that would make a strong post for her fence. Her awareness settled on a small pioneer cemetery a few kilometres south, nestled in a grove of old-growth cedars. It was a place heavy with the stories of hard-won lives, of births and deaths and a stubborn refusal to be broken by a harsh new land. It was a reservoir of human endurance, a different, grittier flavour of energy than the river's wild power. It would have to be the next point.

The drive was punctuated by a new and unwelcome sensation. The generalized static she had felt all day was coalescing, sharpening into a focused point of attention. It was no longer a background hum of wrongness; it was a deliberate, searching probe. Morda had felt the ripple. She had felt the tiny act of defiance and was now turning her gaze, her vast and empty awareness, in Elara's direction. It felt like being watched through a one-way mirror by something that didn't have eyes, a cold and clinical curiosity that made the hairs on her neck stand on end. *There you are,* the feeling implied, a note of mocking familiarity in the psychic pressure. *I wondered when you’d stop hiding.* The sensation was a violation, stripping away her anonymity and leaving her feeling horribly exposed on the rain-swept roads of her own town.

She pulled off the main road onto a narrow lane that ended at a wrought-iron gate. The Murrayville Cemetery. The air here was not just cold, it was desolate. The blight had sunk its teeth deep into this place. The ancient cedars that stood sentinel over the graves seemed to droop, their boughs heavy with a weariness that went beyond the weight of the rain. The moss on the weathered headstones looked grey and brittle, and the names carved into the granite—MacLeod, Stewart, Henderson—were harder to read, not because of physical erosion, but because the very memory of them was being consumed. The void was not just draining the life from the living things; it was trying to un-write history, to erase the stories of the dead until they were nothing more than anonymous dust.

Elara pushed through the gate, the rusted latch groaning in protest. She walked past the tilting, moss-eaten angels and obelisks, her feet sinking into the sodden earth. The psychic pressure intensified, the whispers of futility growing louder as she approached the centre of the small graveyard. She could feel Morda’s will pressing in, a blanket of apathy designed to smother all effort. Elara reached into her satchel and her fingers closed around the familiar, tarnished shape of the child’s silver locket. It was cool to the touch, its inherent warmth dampened by the surrounding cold.

She held it tight in her fist, standing between the graves of a husband and wife who had died within a week of each other in the winter of 1892. She didn't just focus on the locket's past this time; she used it as a lens, projecting its century of concentrated love and devotion outward. She forced herself to think of the people buried beneath her feet, not as names, but as lives. She pictured a farmer’s rough, calloused hands, a mother singing a lullaby, a child’s laughter echoing through the trees, the shared grief and quiet strength of a community carving a life from the wilderness. She poured her own energy into the act, weaving a tapestry of memory and emotion, pushing back against the encroaching grey fog of oblivion. The locket in her palm grew warm, then hot, a burning point of focus in the cold.

The response was immediate and violent. A frigid gust of wind tore through the cedars, carrying the stench of rot and burnt sugar from the gardens. It was a physical manifestation of Morda’s fury. The whispers of despair in her mind were no longer a subtle temptation; they became a direct, venomous sneer, coalescing into a semblance of a voice she knew too well. *Still playing with trinkets, Elara? Still building little sandcastles of sentiment?* The thought, not her own, slid into her mind like a shard of ice. *They’re gone. All of them. Their love didn't save them. Their stories are just ink and stone, and both will turn to dust. Everything turns to dust.* Elara’s breath hitched, her concentration faltering. The locket’s heat dimmed. The cold surged back in, and for a terrifying second, she felt the truth in the words, the crushing, absolute weight of Morda's nihilism. The fight was no longer about containment. It was a battle for the meaning of anything at all.

For a long moment, she faltered. The cold seeped from the psychic wound into the marrow of her bones, and the locket in her hand felt like a dead thing, a lump of meaningless metal. Morda’s nihilism was a perfect acid, dissolving the bonds of sentiment and story that held Elara’s magic together. What was a century of love against the infinite, uncaring void? What was one family’s forgotten story against the relentless march of entropy? The names on the stones blurred again, the cedars sagged, and the weight of every lost cause in history settled onto her shoulders. Pip the terrier had been right to whine and retreat; the smart thing to do was to run, to hide, to find a deep hole and wait for the end. The urge to simply drop the locket, to turn and walk away, to let the comfortable grey numbness take her, was overwhelming.

But as Morda’s poison filled her, a spark of pure, stubborn anger ignited in the depths of her exhaustion. It wasn't the hot, flashy anger of righteous fury, but the cold, hard anger of a librarian whose books are being burned. Morda was wrong. Not wrong that things ended—that was an inescapable truth. She was wrong about what it meant. The love that filled the locket wasn't valuable because it was eternal; it was valuable because it had existed at all, a brief, brilliant flame in the darkness. The lives buried here weren't meaningless because they were over; their meaning was in the living of them, in the choices they made and the community they built. The story wasn't a lie just because it had an ending. The ending was part of what gave it shape. Clinging to that thought, a piece of driftwood in a sea of despair, Elara pushed back. She poured not just her energy into the locket, but her entire conviction. *You are wrong. It all mattered.*

The silver locket in her palm flared with a white-hot heat that was almost painful. It was not the gentle warmth of memory, but the searing, purifying fire of a truth being forged under pressure. The voice in her head didn't just fade; it recoiled, shrieking in silent, psychic agony as if it had touched something holy. The oppressive cold shattered like a sheet of ice, and the air rushed back into the graveyard, clean and smelling of cedar and wet earth. The names on the headstones stood out in sharp relief once more, not as markers of the dead, but as testament to the lived. A small, brown wren, which had been hiding motionless in the branches of a cedar, burst into a defiant, trilling song. The second anchor was set, a knot of story and memory tied so tight that the void could find no way to unravel it.

The moment the pressure vanished, Elara staggered, her knees threatening to buckle. She leaned against a granite headstone, its surface cold but blessedly solid, the locket dropping from her nerveless fingers into the damp grass. The world swam in a grey haze of pure exhaustion. The battle had lasted only a few minutes, but it had taken more from her than the entire struggle five years ago. This was personal. Morda wasn't just feeding; she was arguing. She was trying to convert the world to her own bleak faith, and she had used their old friendship as a weapon, aiming her words at the specific vulnerabilities she knew Elara possessed. Elara picked up the locket, its heat now subsided to a gentle, steady warmth, and slipped it back into her satchel. Every muscle ached as she forced herself to walk, step by leaden step, back to the iron gate and the fragile safety of her car.

Slumped in the driver's seat, she watched the rain trace paths down the windshield. The humming sanctuary of the cemetery behind her felt small, an island in a vast, hungry sea. And she knew, with a certainty that chilled her more than Morda's presence, that her plan was a fool's errand. Building a fence was a strategy for containing a beast of flesh and blood, something that could be held by barriers. Morda was a philosophical plague. The void would not be stopped by a few anchors of sentiment. It would seep through the cracks, it would flow over the top, it would patiently wait for Elara to exhaust herself and then it would consume everything, her anchors included. She was playing checkers against an opponent who was slowly removing the board itself. Defending was a losing game.

A cold, grim clarity settled over her. The keeper of small things was a role for a time of peace. This was a time of war. And in this war, the only possible victory was not to reinforce the world, but to disarm the enemy. The problem wasn't the blight; the blight was a symptom. The problem was Morda. The problem was the bottomless hunger. And for Elara, the quiet woman who wanted to be left alone, the most terrifying thought of all began to take shape. She had to stop running. She had to stop hiding in her quiet corners and mending the edges. She had to turn and face the source. She couldn't fight the hunger, but perhaps she could find what was being fed. She had to become a hunter, not of a monster, but of a reason. Somewhere, buried deep beneath the ravenous Devourer, was the ghost of a girl who knew how to find lucky clovers. To save her world, Elara would have to risk everything to find her.

The decision, once made, settled not with the righteous fire of a hero’s calling, but with the cold, heavy finality of a terminal diagnosis. In the cramped quiet of her car, with the scent of the resurrected cedars and damp earth from the cemetery filling the air, Elara understood. She could spend the rest of her life—however long that might be—running along the perimeter of Morda’s blight, plugging holes in the dike with her dwindling energy and her collection of meaningful things. She might even save a parkette, a field, a block of houses. But the ocean of hunger would still rise, and she would eventually be exhausted, and then she would be consumed. And so would everything she had briefly protected.

To face Morda was not a choice; it was the only option left that wasn't a form of slow suicide. But how? Her magic was useless against a direct assault. Throwing her quiet, practical craft at the Devourer would be like trying to patch a black hole with a quilt. The futility of it was Morda’s greatest weapon. Yet, Elara’s skills were not in fighting, but in finding. She read the history of places, found lost things, soothed jangled nerves. She was a diviner of the unseen, a reader of residue. Perhaps that was the key. She couldn't fight the hunger, but maybe, just maybe, she could find its source. Not the geographical source—that was Sendall Gardens, a gaping wound that was merely the latest feeding ground. She needed to find the original wound, the place in Morda’s own history where the unraveling had begun.

The drive back to her bungalow was a journey through a world she now saw with terrifying clarity. The muted colours and drained energy were no longer just a symptom of a psychic illness; they were tactics. She saw the way the blight avoided places of strong, communal belief—a bustling Sikh temple glowed with a fierce, protective light, while the soulless, big-box retail centre next to it was a grey pit of spiritual exhaustion. Morda was moving intelligently, following the path of least resistance, feeding on the shallow, the transient, the forgotten. This wasn't a mindless hunger. It was a strategic one. The thought was somehow more chilling than anything else.

Back inside her house, the quiet no longer felt like a fragile shield. It was the quiet of a hunter’s blind. Her workshop, with its neatly organized jars and maps, seemed like the domain of a different woman, someone naïve and hopeful. She walked past the bench where the hagstone and salt pouch sat, their purpose now feeling small and insufficient. They were tools for mending, for preserving. She needed a different kind of tool now. A tool for excavation. She crossed the room to a large, cedar-lined trunk in the corner, a piece she had refinished herself years ago. It held things she rarely looked at, relics not of her craft, but of her life before Langley, before the quiet, before she had learned to be so thoroughly alone. She lifted the heavy lid, and the scent of dried lavender and old paper rose to meet her.

Her fingers brushed past bundles of letters tied with faded ribbon, a high school yearbook, a collection of concert ticket stubs. They were the anchors of her own history, the things she had kept to remind herself of the person she had been. Deeper down, beneath a folded wool sweater she hadn't worn in a decade, her fingers found it. A small, wooden box. Inside, nestled on a bed of faded velvet, was a single, intricately carved wooden bird. A wren, its head cocked, its tiny form bursting with an implied energy that was so lifelike it seemed it might break into song. Morda had carved it for her, a gift for Elara’s sixteenth birthday, back when their magic was a shared, wondrous secret, a game of finding lucky clovers and whispering to the wind. Morda’s hands, which now only took, had once been capable of such patient, generous creation.

Elara picked up the wren. It felt cold, inert. The vibrant life Morda had carved into it was dormant, almost extinguished by the void its creator had become. But it wasn't gone. Deep within the grain of the wood, a faint, stubborn spark of that long-ago intention remained. It was a signature, a psychic fingerprint of the girl Morda had been. This was not a tool of defence. This was a compass. Closing her eyes, she held the small bird to her chest, not pushing her energy into it, but listening to it, attuning herself to that faint, residual spark of her friend. She didn't ask it to fight the darkness; she asked it to show her where the darkness was born. *Where did you break?* she whispered, not with her voice, but with her soul.

The answer wasn't a map or a name. It was a sudden, brutal flood of borrowed emotion that buckled her knees. It was the taste of ash, the shattering of glass, and a wave of grief so profound, so absolute, it was indistinguishable from suffocation. And beneath the grief, a cold, hard knot of betrayal. It was the psychic residue of a wound that had never healed, a wound that had festered and turned into a hunger for everything else to feel as empty as she did. Woven into that torrent of feeling was the faint, ghostly image of a place: a dilapidated white farmhouse with a wraparound porch, set back from a country road, a single, massive oak tree standing sentinel in a fallow field beside it. The old Henderson place, out in Glen Valley. Morda’s childhood home. The place her parents had lost to the bank, the place that had been the backdrop to the tragedy that had unmade their family, and unmade Morda herself.

Elara opened her eyes, gasping for breath, the force of the vision leaving her dizzy and nauseated. Morda hadn’t chosen Sendall Gardens at random. She was moving through the valley, erasing her own past, consuming the places that held her pain. The Henderson farmhouse would be next. Or perhaps, it would be last. The source of it all. Elara straightened up, her resolve hardening from a grim necessity into a sharp, painful point. She slipped the wooden wren into her jacket pocket. It was the only tool she would take. She walked out of her workshop, leaving the door open, and went to the front of the house. She paused, her hand on the doorknob, and took one last look at the quiet, ordered life she had built for herself. It was already a ghost. The rain had stopped. In the bruised light of the evening, she got into her car and turned east, driving not away from the static and the cold, but directly into its heart.

The eastward drive along Fraser Highway was a journey into the heart of the distortion. The familiar landscape of berry farms and equestrian centres began to subtly warp at the edges of Elara’s vision. Telephone poles seemed to lean in at unnatural angles, and the vibrant green of the fields looked sickly and yellowed under the bruised twilight sky. The steady pull she had felt was now a relentless, psychic undertow, dragging her towards its source. The static in her head was no longer a random crackle but had resolved into a low, keening hum, a single note of perpetual grief that vibrated in her teeth. Other drivers seemed to feel it too; she saw a flash of road rage, a horn blaring for no reason, a general agitation that curdled the air more than the exhaust fumes ever could. The world was coming unwired, and she was driving straight towards the spool.

She turned off the highway onto a narrow country lane that wound through a tunnel of tall cottonwoods. Here, the effect was suffocating. The air grew thick and heavy, pressing in on the car until she felt like she was driving at the bottom of a deep, cold lake. Then the lane opened up, and she saw it. The white farmhouse stood on a small rise, stark against the darkening sky. It was exactly as the vision had shown her: two stories, a wraparound porch sagging on one end, and a single, massive oak tree in the field beside it. The oak was a skeletal horror, its great limbs bare and clawing at the sky, its bark peeling away from the trunk in leprous sheets. It was not dead from disease or age; it had been hollowed out, its life-force drunk to the dregs, and it now stood as a monument to Morda’s hunger.

Parking the car on the gravel shoulder, Elara switched off the engine. The silence that descended was absolute. It was not the absence of sound, but the active negation of it. Her own breathing seemed unnaturally loud, her heartbeat a frantic drum against the crushing stillness. The cold was a living thing, crawling over the hood of her car and seeping through the glass to touch her skin. This was not the aftermath of a feeding; this was the lair. The place where the hunger slept and dreamed. Her hand went to her jacket pocket, her fingers closing around the smooth, carved shape of the wooden wren. It was cool, but it was solid. A tiny, real thing in a world that felt like it was dissolving into mist.

Each step up the overgrown driveway was an act of will. The very ground seemed to resist her, the dead, grey grass crunching under her Blundstones like fine glass. The house loomed, a blind and rotting façade. More than just dilapidated, it felt curated in its emptiness, like a museum exhibit of despair. The front door hung open on a single hinge, a black, gaping mouth inviting her into the void. She climbed the creaking steps of the porch, her gaze falling on a set of faint, shallow scratches in the wood by the doorframe—the kind a family makes to mark their children’s height. They were barely visible, almost erased, the memories they represented fading into the all-consuming nothingness. It was a small, devastating detail, a quiet testament to the methodical nature of Morda’s self-erasure.

Stepping over the threshold was like plunging into ice water. The world outside, with its bruised sky and skeletal tree, vanished, replaced by a monochrome reality of grey on grey. There were no shadows because there was no light source. There was no dust motes dancing in the air because the air was perfectly, unnaturally still. The house was not empty of furniture; it was empty of space, empty of dimension. Looking into the living room was like looking at a photograph that had been bleached of all detail, leaving only the faint impression of a room that had once existed. Her own thoughts felt slow and sluggish, the insidious whispers of futility returning, telling her to turn back, that there was nothing here to find, nothing here to save.

She forced her hand into her pocket, her numb fingers fumbling for the wooden wren. As she pulled it out, it became the only point of focus in the featureless void. Holding it, she closed her eyes, shutting out the sensory deprivation of the house and focusing entirely on the small object in her palm. It was no longer just a compass; it was a lantern. She pushed her intention into it, not the defiant fire she had used in the cemetery, but a gentle, questioning warmth. *Show me. Show me where it hurts.* A faint, almost imperceptible warmth spread from the wren, and she felt a subtle pull, a current in the stagnant ocean of the house. It guided her forward, one shuffling step at a time, through the ghostly outline of a dining room and towards a dark staircase that rose into the deeper grey above.

The pull grew stronger as she ascended the stairs, each step a groan of ancient, soul-tired wood. The air thinned, becoming impossibly cold, and the humming grief she had felt in the car intensified until it was a physical vibration in her bones. The wren guided her down a short hallway to the last door on the left. Here, the cold was so absolute it felt like a physical burn. The wood of the door was smooth, scoured of all paint and texture. Taking a deep, ragged breath that didn't seem to fill her lungs, she pushed it open. The room beyond was a perfect wound. A child’s bedroom, stripped not just of its contents but of its very essence. On the floorboards, she saw it: a dark, indelible stain, a psychic scar so deep and old it seemed to have become part of the very fabric of the house.

And in the centre of the room, the nothingness began to gather. The grey haze thickened, swirled, and compacted into a shimmering distortion, a human-shaped absence that seemed to bend the featureless room around it. There were no eyes, no face, no form, but Elara felt its gaze on her with an intensity that stripped her bare. The voice slid into her mind, no longer a whisper or a sneer, but a thing of calm, conversational cruelty.

*You came,* said the hole in the world. *I knew you would. You always did have to fix things, Elara. Even the things that are meant to stay broken.*

Elara did not flinch. She stood her ground in the heart of the cold, her fingers tightening around the small, carved wren in her pocket. The pressure of Morda’s presence was a physical weight, a force designed to crush and silence, but the small, stubborn warmth of her own conviction was its own kind of shield. She drew a breath, a real one this time, that tasted of grief and memory. Her reply was not spoken aloud but pushed into the suffocating stillness, a clear, quiet thought projected directly at the absence before her.

*“Nothing is meant to stay broken, Morda. Some things just need help finding their way back together.”*

A flicker of something—amusement, perhaps, or a cold form of pity—rippled through the void. The human-shaped hole seemed to lean forward, the featureless space of the room bending around it. *“Still the mender. You see a shattered vase and think only of the glue. You never stop to ask if the vase wanted to be a mosaic instead. Or perhaps, just sand.”* The voice was patient, pedagogical, the voice of a teacher explaining a difficult but obvious truth to a slow student. *“You can’t find me, Elara, because you refuse to look in the right place. You’re looking for a person. I am showing you a conclusion. Let me make it clearer for you.”*

The world dissolved. The oppressive grey uniformity of the room fractured, not into darkness, but into a ghostly, saturated memory. Suddenly, Elara was no longer standing in a ruin but in a little girl's bedroom, vibrant and alive. Sunlight, thick with dust motes, streamed through a clean window. Flowered wallpaper, now a faint ghost, was bright and cheerful. There was a small desk, a messy bed, and on the floor, a young Morda, no more than twelve, was concentrating with fierce intensity on a block of wood, a carving knife clutched in her hand. The air hummed with the same creative energy Elara had once known in her, a focused, joyful magic that coaxed the shape of a bird from the unyielding grain. Elara was an invisible ghost in this memory, a silent witness to a past that felt more real than the present.

Then the memory soured. The sunlight vanished as if a switch had been thrown. The sound of shouting erupted from downstairs, jagged and ugly, full of words like ‘foreclosure’ and ‘failure’. The joyful hum of creation from young Morda curdled into a tight knot of fear. She dropped her carving knife and went to the door, peering down the hallway. The memory-Elara was pulled along, her perspective tethered to Morda’s. She saw Morda’s father storm up the stairs, his face a mask of pale, sweating fury. He didn’t seem to see his daughter. He was ranting, not to anyone, but to the house itself, to the universe. "This place," he spat, his voice cracking with desperation, "this land, this whole damned life… it’s worthless. It’s all worthless. I wish we could just burn it all down and walk away from the ashes."

He didn’t see the way his daughter flinched, how his words, flung out in a moment of despair, landed on her like a physical blow. He didn't see the way her own burgeoning, sensitive magic took his desperate, ugly wish and interpreted it as a command, an incantation. He didn't see the flicker of heat in the walls, the faint smell of ozone. He just stormed into his own room and slammed the door. But Morda felt it. She felt the spark of her own power, twisted by her father's grief and rage, take root in the house's dry, old bones. She had wanted to fix it, to soothe his pain with her quiet magic, but his rejection of everything, his wish for nothingness, had poisoned her gift at its source. That was the betrayal. Not the loss of the house, but the declaration that everything she loved was worthless, and the accidental, horrific granting of that wish.

The vision fractured, the smell of phantom smoke and the taste of bitter ash flooding Elara's senses. The cheerful room dissolved back into the grey, featureless void, the cold rushing back in to fill the space where the painful memory had been. Morda's voice returned, stripped of its cruel amusement, now just a flat, dead thing. *“He was right. It was worthless. The love, the memories, the house, me. All of it. The only thing of value that day was the fire that took it all away. The only truth is the ash. The hunger isn't a flaw, Elara. It is a tool. It is the most honest thing in the world. It strips away the lies of meaning and leaves only the peace of the void.”*

Elara swayed, the weight of that twelve-year-old’s grief threatening to drown her. She saw it all now. The Devourer wasn't born of malice, but of a child's broken heart, of a magical gift that had curdled into a curse. The hunger was a frantic, desperate attempt to prove her father right, to make the whole world as empty and worthless as he had made her feel in that single, shattering moment. But Morda was wrong. Elara felt a deep, aching certainty in her soul. He wasn't right. He was just a man in pain, a man who had said something terrible and unthinking. Slowly, painfully, Elara raised her hand, opening her palm. There, in the centre of the absolute nothingness of the room, lay the small wooden wren. It was a lie to Morda's truth. It was a creation, an object of beauty and intention, made by the same girl who had accidentally lit the fire.

*“He was wrong,”* Elara projected, her own voice shaking but clear. *“He was a heartbroken man who said a monstrous thing. But this,”* she pushed the thought of the wren, the memory of its creation, the feel of the wood, the focused joy, directly at the void, *“This is who you were. This is the truth you’re trying to burn. Not the fire. Not the ash. This.”*

The thought, a pure, clean note of defiance, struck the void not like a weapon, but like a tuning fork. For a timeless moment, the human-shaped absence simply held it, as if considering an utterly alien concept. Then, the stillness broke. A tremor of violent negation ran through the shape, and the cold in the room dropped to a level of soul-crushing intensity. The voice, no longer calm or conversational, was a shriek of pure psychic outrage that ripped through Elara’s mind. *LIES!* The word was not a sound but a destructive force, aimed with surgical precision at the small wooden bird in Elara’s hand. The wren, which had been a point of focus, suddenly felt like it was dissolving, its form becoming indistinct, its carved feathers blurring. She felt the memory within it being actively unwritten, the joy of its creation being systematically erased by a wave of absolute, annihilating despair.

Elara’s breath caught in a pained gasp, but she did not let go. Her fingers, numb with cold, clamped down on the small bird with a desperate strength she didn't know she possessed. She understood, in that terrible instant, that presenting the truth was not enough. She had to become its advocate, its defender, its living vessel. The void was trying to make the wren worthless, to prove its own bleak thesis by destroying the evidence against it. Pouring more of her own energy into it would be futile; that was just more fuel. Instead, she let her mind fall into the wren, not to power it, but to inhabit it. She flooded the fading memory of its creation with her own. She remembered Morda’s face, lit by a summer afternoon, as she explained how you had to follow the grain of the wood, not fight it. She remembered the shared thrill of their secret magic, the whisper of the wind in the branches of the great oak when it had been alive and majestic. She remembered Morda giving her the wren, a shy, proud gesture that spoke of a friendship that had felt as solid and real as the earth beneath their feet.

The room became a battleground of warring realities. The wren in Elara’s hand pulsed with a furious, defiant heat, a composite glow of Morda’s forgotten creation and Elara’s stubborn recollection. The grey, featureless void around them began to flicker and tear. For a moment, the room was filled with the roar and the searing orange light of a house fire, the scent of burning memories thick in the air. Then it would flash back to the sun-drenched bedroom, the scent of fresh-cut wood and the sound of a young girl’s humming. The voice in Elara’s head was no longer a coherent scream but a frantic, chaotic storm of pain, denial, and a grief so profound it threatened to pull her under. *It burned! It was all worthless! Let it go! Let it be nothing!* The force of the psychic storm pushed against her, a hurricane of negation trying to pry her fingers from the one small object that held a different story. Elara sank to her knees on the stained floorboards, her body trembling with the strain, every ounce of her being focused on a single, unwavering thought: *It mattered. You mattered.*

Then, something broke. Not Elara, not the wren, but the void itself. The frantic, warring images ceased. The psychic scream died into a soundless echo. In the centre of the room, the human-shaped absence wavered, lost its cohesion, and for a single, heart-stopping second, it collapsed inward and revealed what it had been hiding. It was not a monster or a hole in the world, but the image of Morda, a young woman of perhaps eighteen, standing in the rain-soaked, charred ruins of her home. Her face was hollowed out, not by hunger, but by a grief so absolute it had consumed her from the inside out. This was the moment. The instant after the fire, after the loss, when the broken-hearted girl had made a terrible, silent vow to make the whole world as empty as her own heart. And from that image, from the epicentre of all that pain, a sound emerged. Not a psychic echo, but a real, ragged, human sob that tore through the dead silence of the house.

The oppressive weight vanished so suddenly that Elara gasped, stumbling forward onto her hands. The profound, unnatural cold retreated, leaving behind only the damp chill of a long-abandoned building. The grey, featureless deprivation bled away, and the room resolved back into a place of peeling wallpaper, grimy floorboards, and a single window looking out onto a bruised and darkening sky. The house was just a house again. And where the shimmering void had been, a woman was curled on the floor. She was gaunt, dressed in drab, worn clothes, her dark hair lank and matted. Her thin shoulders shook with wrenching, silent sobs. The Devourer was gone. The hunger was quiet. All that was left was Morda, shipwrecked on the shore of her own unending sorrow, finally, terribly, found.

For a long time, Elara could only kneel on the dusty floorboards, her own breath coming in ragged, painful gulps as the adrenaline and psychic strain receded, leaving behind a bone-deep weariness that felt as old as the house itself. The carved wren in her hand was just a piece of wood now, its borrowed heat and defiant light gone, its purpose served. The air, no longer a weaponized void, was thick with the mundane smells of mould and damp rot, a relief so profound it was almost dizzying. The only sound was the heartbreakingly human sound of Morda’s weeping, a raw, desolate noise that seemed to pull at the very foundations of the ruined house.

Slowly, stiffly, Elara pushed herself to her feet. Every instinct screamed at her to flee, to get out of this place of grief and decay and back to her small, ordered world. The threat was gone. The Devourer had been vanquished. But the mender in her, the part of her that soothed panicked cats and coaxed lost things from the darkness, could not turn away from this single, shattered piece of her own past. The hunter’s job was done, but the friend’s work, she realized with a sinking heart, was just beginning.
